As a 35-year-old male Japanese employee living in Tokyo, I can see both sides of the argument. While it is true that a good manager should be able to answer their subordinates' questions, there are times when that may not be possible.

On one hand, a manager who is unable to provide clear and concise answers to their subordinates' questions may give the impression of being unprepared or inefficient. This could lead to a lack of trust and confidence in the manager's ability to lead the team effectively.
